thread.title: Cavaliers sign forward Tristan Thompson to 5-year, $82 million contract
thread.title_full: Cavaliers sign forward Tristan Thompson to 5-year, $82 million contract

title: Cavaliers sign forward Tristan Thompson to 5-year, $82 million contract
text:
Cavaliers sign forward Tristan Thompson to 5-year, $82 million contract 
THE SPORTS XCHANGE Thursday, October 22, 2015 03:35 PM EDT | Updated: Thursday, October 22, 2015 03:38 PM EDT In this Friday, May 22, 2015 file photo, Cleveland Cavaliers center Tristan Thompson (13) moves past Atlanta Hawks forward Paul Millsap (4) during the second half in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals of the NBA basketball playoffs in Atlanta. The Cavaliers and free-agent forward Tristan Thompson have agreed in principle on a five-year, $82 million contract, ending his holdout, Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015. (AP Photo/David Goldman, File) Report an error INDEPENDENCE, OHIO - 
Tristan Thompson and the Cleveland Cavaliers ended an impasse with a five-year contract signed Thursday. The deal is worth $82 million and is fully guaranteed. 
No player or team options are included in the contract, which appears to be a massive victory for Thompson. 
Thompson's agent, Rich Paul, first leaked Wednesday that the deal worth $16.4 million per season was in the offing. 
"It's been a long summer of grinding and hard work but now it's back to The Land to take care of some unfinished business. #HappyToBeBack #ALLin," Thompson tweeted. 
Thompson and the Cavaliers had not been able to end a standoff that started on the first day of free agency in July when it was reported that the sides were close to an agreement. 
The 24-year-old sought a max contract of five years at $94 million or three years at $53 million, but the Cavs previously would not offer more than $80 million. 
Cavs superstar LeBron James urged the team to re-sign Thompson throughout the summer and into the preseason, saying the situation was a distraction to the team. Thompson rejected a one-year, $6.9 million qualifying offer from the Cavs and appeared ready to hold out into the regular season. 
Thompson averaged 8.5 points and 8.0 rebounds off the bench for the Cavs last season but started 15 games during the playoffs after Kevin Love was sidelined with a shoulder injury and averaged 9.6 points and 10.8 rebounds during Cleveland's run to the NBA Finals.
